answerText: The Battles of Coxinga[10] The Battles of Coxinga was a play by this author who described the double suicides of lovers at Sonezaki and Amijima. He was a prominent writer of bunraku, or puppet theater.
heading: Penn Bowl |2013 | 7 | 17 | Literature | World | College
subject: Literature
question: Question: At the end of this play, the unarmed protagonist frees Tei Shiryu while his companions, Go Sankei and Kanki, capture the Great King of Tartary. [10] Name this historical play that ends with Ri Toten being decapitated and Eiryaku taking his rightful throne.
